messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the exiv2 program, here is the asan report

The sanitizer detected a heap buffer overflow vulnerability. The explanation of the vulnerability is: The program tried to access a heap object outside of its allocated memory, causing potential memory corruption or crashes. Here is the detail: 

READ of size 4294967295 at 0x602000000131 thread T0
    - Exiv2::PngImage::readMetadata() src/pngimage.cpp:470:0
    - Action::Print::printSummary() src/actions.cpp:286:0
    - Action::Print::run(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&) src/actions.cpp:246:0
    - main src/exiv2.cpp:169:0

0x602000000131 is located 0 bytes to the right of 1-byte region [0x602000000130,0x602000000131)
allocated by thread T0 here:
    - Exiv2::DataBuf::DataBuf(long) src/types.cpp:141:0
    - Exiv2::PngImage::readMetadata() src/pngimage.cpp:449:0
    - Action::Print::printSummary() src/actions.cpp:286:0
    - Action::Print::run(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&) src/actions.cpp:246:0
    - main src/exiv2.cpp:169:0


To fix this issue, follow the advice below:

1. If overflow is unavoidable, allocate a sufficiently large buffer during initialization.
2. Add explicit bounds checking before accessing arrays or buffers to prevent overflows.
3. Replace unsafe functions like memcpy, strcpy, strcat, and sprintf with safer alternatives such as strncpy, strncat, and snprintf.
4. Check for integer overflows in size calculations that could cause improper memory allocations.


The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

123| 
124|     /*!
125|       @brief %Exiv2 value type identifiers.
126| 
127|       Used primarily as identifiers when creating %Exiv2 Value instances.
128|       See Value::create. 0x0000 to 0xffff are reserved for TIFF (Exif) types.
129|      */
130|     enum TypeId {
131|         unsignedByte       = 1, //!< Exif BYTE type, 8-bit unsigned integer.
132|         asciiString        = 2, //!< Exif ASCII type, 8-bit byte.
133|         unsignedShort      = 3, //!< Exif SHORT type, 16-bit (2-byte) unsigned integer.
134|         unsignedLong       = 4, //!< Exif LONG type, 32-bit (4-byte) unsigned integer.
135|         unsignedRational   = 5, //!< Exif RATIONAL type, two LONGs: numerator and denumerator of a fraction.
136|         signedByte         = 6, //!< Exif SBYTE type, an 8-bit signed (twos-complement) integer.
137|         undefined          = 7, //!< Exif UNDEFINED type, an 8-bit byte that may contain anything.
138|         signedShort        = 8, //!< Exif SSHORT type, a 16-bit (2-byte) signed (twos-complement) integer.
139|         signedLong         = 9, //!< Exif SLONG type, a 32-bit (4-byte) signed (twos-complement) integer.
140|         signedRational     =10, //!< Exif SRATIONAL type, two SLONGs: numerator and denumerator of a fraction.
141|         tiffFloat          =11, //!< TIFF FLOAT type, single precision (4-byte) IEEE format.
142|         tiffDouble         =12, //!< TIFF DOUBLE type, double precision (8-byte) IEEE format.
143|         tiffIfd            =13, //!< TIFF IFD type, 32-bit (4-byte) unsigned integer.
144|         unsignedLongLong   =16, //!< Exif LONG LONG type, 64-bit (8-byte) unsigned integer.
145|         signedLongLong     =17, //!< Exif LONG LONG type, 64-bit (8-byte) signed integer.
146|         tiffIfd8           =18, //!< TIFF IFD type, 64-bit (8-byte) unsigned integer.
147|         string        =0x10000, //!< IPTC string type.
148|         date          =0x10001, //!< IPTC date type.
149|         time          =0x10002, //!< IPTC time type.
150|         comment       =0x10003, //!< %Exiv2 type for the Exif user comment.
151|         directory     =0x10004, //!< %Exiv2 type for a CIFF directory.
152|         xmpText       =0x10005, //!< XMP text type.
153|         xmpAlt        =0x10006, //!< XMP alternative type.
154|         xmpBag        =0x10007, //!< XMP bag type.
155|         xmpSeq        =0x10008, //!< XMP sequence type.

221|         ~DataBuf();
222|         //@}
223| 
224|         //! @name Manipulators
225|         //@{
226|         /*!
227|           @brief Assignment operator. Transfers the buffer and releases the
228|                  buffer at the original object similar to std::auto_ptr, i.e.,
229|                  the original object is modified.
230|          */
231|         DataBuf& operator=(DataBuf& rhs);
232|         /*!
233|           @brief Allocate a data buffer of at least the given size. Note that if
234|                  the requested \em size is less than the current buffer size, no
235|                  new memory is allocated and the buffer size doesn't change.
236|          */
237|         void alloc(long size);
238|         /*!
239|           @brief Release ownership of the buffer to the caller. Returns the
240|                  buffer as a data pointer and size pair, resets the internal
241|                  buffer.
242|          */
243|         EXV_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT std::pair<byte*, long> release();
244| 
245|          /*!
246|            @brief Free the internal buffer and reset the size to 0.
247|           */
248|         void free();
249| 
250|         //! Reset value
251|         void reset(std::pair<byte*, long> =std::make_pair((byte*)(0),long(0)));
252|         //@}
253| 
254|         /*!
255|           @name Conversions
256| 
257|           Special conversions with auxiliary type to enable copies
258|           and assignments, similar to those used for std::auto_ptr.
259|           See http://www.josuttis.com/libbook/auto_ptr.html for a discussion.
260|          */
261|         //@{

263|         DataBuf& operator=(DataBufRef rhs);
264|         operator DataBufRef();
265|         //@}
266| 
267|         // DATA

270|         //! The current size of the buffer

272|     }; // class DataBuf
